Recent progress and development on polymeric nanomaterials for
photothermal therapy: A brief overview
Yingge Shi a,# , Meiying Liu a,# , Fengjie Deng a , Guangjian Zeng a , Qing Wan a , Xiaoyong Zhang a,* , Yen Wei b,*
Photothermal therapy (PTT) is a rapid expanding area with great research attention and has emerged as a promising
method for cancer treatment recently. The PTT is mainly relied on the local heating effect from photothermal agents
(PTAs), which can transform the energy of light into heat. Various inorganic PTAs such as gold nanorods, carbon
nanomaterials, layered transition metal dichalcogenides and various polymeric nanomaterials have been developed for
PTT applications. However, the inorganic PTAs are normally poor biodradable and potential toxic. Polymeric PTAs possess
many advantages as compared with the inorganic ones and have become the focus for PTT applications very recently. In
this article, the recent advance and progress of polymers such as conjugated polymers and melanin-like polymers for PTT
applications will be introduced. The future direction, challenges and potential development of polymeric PTAs for efficient
PTT are also addressed. The objective of this review is to give a brief overview of this emerging field to polymer chemists
and material scientists.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Cancer is a type of malignant and fetal disease, which has
been regarded as one of the most vicious diseases threatening human beings. 1, 2 The treatment of cancer through traditional
therapy modalities such as surgery, chemotherapy and
radiotherapy have demonstrated to be effective in eradicating
the tumors, however they also show some disadvantages,
which include severe side effects, poor patient compliance,
destruction of immune systems, high cost and low therapeutic efficiency. 3-6 Therefore, the development of alternative non-
invasive cancer treatment modalities (e.g. microwave therapy,
radiofrequency therapy, ultrasound therapy and phototherapy) is highly urgent. 7-9 Among them, the
phototherapy modalities have attracted the most attention
and analysis over the years owing to their high efficiency, spatial specificity and remote control capability. 10-12
Photothermal therapy (PTT) is one of phototherapy models,
which relied on converting energy of light into thermal through irradiation of photothermal agents (PTAs). 13, 14
Generally, PTAs applied in PTT have quite strict requirements
and high standards including the absorbance of near infrared
(NIR) light, high photothermal conversion efficiency, high
photostability, suitable size, uniform shape, excellent
dispersibility, good biocompatibility and low cytotoxicity.
So far, numerous PTAs according to the rules have been
developed continuously. Based on their compositions, PTAs
can be mainly divided into two categories, inorganic and
organic PTAs. Metal-based nanomaterials (gold
nanomaterials), layered transition metal dichalcogenides (e.g.
MoS2, WS2, WSe2), carbon nanomaterials (carbon nanotubes, graphene and their derivatives), quantum dots, upconversion
nanocomposites and black phosphorus quantum dots are outstanding representatives of inorganic PTAs (Scheme. 1). 15-27
Especially gold-based nanomaterials have been widely
explored as their high thermal conversion efficiency and biological inert. 14, 28-30 Carbon nanotubes, graphene and their
derivatives are also famous for their high absorbance in NIR region and low cost. 31-35 More recently, the layered
transition metal dichalcogenides have also demonstrated to be
highly promising for cancer hydrothermal treatment applications. 36-38 More recently, the black phosphorus
quantum dots that exhibit desirable degradability and good biocompatibility have also confirmed by Yu et al. 27 They
demonstrated that black phosphorus quantum dots can be
loaded by poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) to form hybrid PTAs,
which show good PTT efficiency and can be degraded into
nontoxic or low-toxic micromolecules (include oligomers and
monomers of PLGA, phosphate and phosphonate) under

physiological environment. However, most of these inorganic
nanomaterials for PTT still have some downsides. For example,
these inorganic nanomaterials are difficult to be used for
biomedical applications and should be firstly modified with
polymers such as polyethylene glycol or targeted agents to
improve their water dispersibility and accumulation in tumor.
Furthermore, most of the inorganic nanomaterials are difficult
to be degraded in vivo. The potential toxicity of these inorganic
nanomaterials should be fully considered for their practical
biomedical applications.
To date, the PTAs based on polymers have raised more and
more research interest for PTT. 39, 40 As compared with
inorganic PTAs, polymeric PTAs are good biodegradable, low
toxicity and possess desirable photothermal conversion
efficiency and high photostability. Some polymeric PTAs such
as NIR dye containing micelles, porphysomes, protein-based PTAs have been reviewed by Liu et al. recently. 41 In this review,
we will mainly focus on two types of polymeric PTAs including
conjugated polymers and melanin-like polymers. The
fabrication, properties and photothermal effects of these
polymeric PTAs were included in the review. The challenge and
future direction of polymeric PTAs for PTT were also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1 Conjugated Polymers
sections.text:
cause delocalization and transition, thus they were efficient in the absorption and conversion energy of light to heat. 42, 43 A
variety of conjugated polymers such as poly(3,4-
ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(4-sytrenesulfonate),
polyaniline, polypyrrole (PPy), poly(2-ethylhexyl
cyclopentadithiophene-co-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole), poly(2-
ethylhexyl cyclopentadithiophene -co- 2,1,3-
benzoselenadiazole) and poly[9,9-bis(4-(2-
ethylhexyl)phenyl)fluorene-alt-co-6,7-bis(4-(hexyloxy)phenyl)-
4,9-di(thiophen-2-yl)-thiadiazoloquinoxaline] (PFTTQ) have been examined for PTT applications previously. 44-49 For
example, Liu et al synthesized a specific polymeric PTAs
derived from poly-(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(4-
styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) for PTT of cancer in vivo (Fig. 2). 50, 51 PEDOT:PSS is a kind of polythiophene derivative and a
routine conductive polymer with NIR absorbance. Previously, it
has been introduced to antistatic coating, supercapacitor, organic solar cells and electric-magnetic shielding industry. 52-54
But few studies have paid attention to PTT based on its NIR
absorbance property. In this work, PEDOT:PSS, formed through
layer-by-layer self-assembly, was then branched with PEG to
improve the biocompatibility of particles (Fig. 2a). The results
proved the nanoparticles with a diameter of 80-90 nm
possessed excellent PTT efficiency. After intravenous injection of PEDOT:PSS-PEG (200 μl, 1 mg mL -1 ) and irradiation by the NIR laser (808 nm, 0.5 W·cm -2 , 5 min) (Fig. 2b), the
temperature of tumor sites was increased from 30 to 51 °C,
which resulted in the tumor volume observably decreased
from the second day. On the other hand, the 4T1 tumor-
bearing mice can survive more than 45 days because the
tumor was fully eliminated (Fig. 2c and 2d).
Fig. 2 (a) PEDOT:PSS-PEG synthesis process, (b) infrared thermal images of 4T1 tumorbearing mice without (upper row) or with (lower row) treatment of PEDOT : PSS-PEG and Laser taken at different time intervals, (c) growth of 4T1 tumors in different groups of mice after treatment, (d) survival curves of mice after various treatments as indicated in (c). (Reproduced from Ref. 50 with permission).

Apart from PEDOT, other conjugated polymers such as
polyaniline and PPy were also employed in PTT applications.
Among them, the PTAs based on polyaniline derivatives have been explored for cancer PTT application extensively. 55, 56 For
example, Yang et al investigated the effect of polyaniline as PTAs in 2011 (Fig. 3a). 55 They took full advantage of the
property that emeraldine base (EB) translated to emeraldine
salt (ES) which was able to absorb NIR laser and produce heat
in the intracellular acidic or oxidative conditions. In vitro, A431
cells were destructed when they were irradiated with NIR laser
in the present of polyaniline nanoparticles after accepting.
Furthermore, the tumor of mice bearing A431 was eradicated
after laser irradiation. Zhou et al. further studied the PTT
application of polyaniline based nanoparticles, which was
synthesized by hydrothermal method, the nanoparticles with a
diameter of 48.5 ± 1.5 nm exhibited concentration-dependent absorbance of NIR region (Fig. 3b). 56 HCT116 tumor in mice
can be eliminated absolutely through treatment with F127-
polyaniline and NIR laser within 5 days. In the next 10 days, no
tumor growth was observed. Besides, the polyaniline
nanoparticles possess low toxicity. Hyaluronic acid–hybridized
polyaniline nanoparticles assembled by one-step oxidativepolymerization was also reported for PTT. 57 The water-soluble
nanoparticles can selectively kill HeLa and HCT-116 cells
bearing tumors in vivo after NIR laser irradiation. In this
system, polyaniline and hyaluronic acid played the role of PTAs
and targeted agent, respectively.
been produced by Liu et al (Fig. 4). 58 Benefited from the
hydrophilic coatings, the nanoparticles with a diameter of 60
nm were stable in physiological environment, which was quite
important to enhance the effect of PTT. When PPy
nanoparticles were exposed to 808 nm laser at different
density, the surface temperature of tumor in mice increased at
a different rate in 5 min. Subsequently, the tumor was
eliminated completely in 5 days. Hu et al. synthesized two
different size PPy particles and found the small size nanoparticles own better PTT. 59 Dai et al. also reported PPy
nanoparticles with a uniform diameter of 46 nm for PTT, especially to the destruction of HeLa cells. 60 In addition,
PPy@Fe3O4 nanoparticles, PEGylated PPy particles and PPy/hemin particles were also researched for PTT. 61-63
Fig. 4 (a) The preparation of PPy nanoparticles, (b) the relationship of temperature increasing and time in different groups, (c) the tumor growth curves of different groups, (d) photos of mice in different groups. (Reproduced from Ref. 58 with permission).
Liu and her group designed a series of PTA based on PFTTQ.
Applying 1,2-distearoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine-N -
[methoxy(polyethyleneglycol)-2000] (DSPE-PEG 2000)
encapsulation matrix, they synthesized PFTTQ nanoparticles
(PFTTQ NPs) by precipitation of PFTTQ (Fig. 5). PFTTQ
nanoparticles showed good biocompatibility to MDA-MB-231
and HeLa cells. Under NIR laser irradiation of 808 nm for 10
min, both MDA-MB-231 and HeLa cells, incubated with PFTTQ
nanoparticles (200 µg/mL), were damaged more than 80%. In
vivo, the PFTTQ NPs also revealed excellent PTT efficiency as
the tumor temperature has risen by 20 °C within 3 min and the
tumor even disappeared in 4 days after dealing with PFTTQ nanoparticles and NIR laser irradiation successively. 49 Although
many previous reports have demonstrated that conjugated
polymers could be used for effective eradicating tumor, the poor
biodegradability and potential toxicity of these conjugated
polymers remains controversial.

sections.heading: 2.2 Melanin-like polymers
sections.text:
Melanin, a kind of polymer existed in various plants and
animals, has been widely studied in antioxidant, radioresistance and anti-neoplastic previously. 64, 65 Meanwhile, it
has a strong absorbance to NIR light and thus be potentially
applied in photoacoustic imaging and photothermal imaging, especially PTT. 66 In a recent report, Chu and coworkers
employed natural melanin (BSM) extracted from black sesame as PTAs and marker to sentinel lymph node (SLN) (Fig. 6). 66 On
day nine, they found the tumor size was close to zero after injection of BSM solution of PBS (5 mg·mL -1 , 70 μl, optimal
dose) and irradiation by NIR laser (808 nm) for 20 min per day.
In addition, BSM had no toxicity towards normal cells but nice
biocompatibility. Stritzker et al. inserted the key gene of
melanogenesis into the oncolytic vaccinia virus strain GLV-
1h68 and GLV-1h324, then injected them into mice bearing
A549 tumor for thermotherapy, optoacoustic imaging and magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. 67 After the exposure to NIR
laser (808 nm) for 2 min, the tumor volume of mice injected
GLV-1h324 was evidently induced. But not that of mice
injected GLV-1h168. On the whole, BSM is effective as a kind
of PTAs and has great potential in cancer therapy and SLN
mapping.
Fig. 6 (a) The preparation of liposome-BSM, (b) representative photographs of mice injected with 70 mL of liposome-BSM containing 5 mg·mL -1 and (c) 10 mg·mL -1 of BSM with the 808 nm laser, (d) the mouse tumors were injected with 70 mL of blank liposomes (100 mg·mL -1 ) with the 808 nm laser, (e) the mouse tumors were injected with 70 mL of liposome-BSM containing 10 mg·mL -1 of BSM without irradiation. (Reproduced from Ref. 66 with permission).
PDA is a melanin-like polymer that has been regarded as an
important macromolecule since the first report of using PDA for fabrication of multifunctional surfaces and materials. 68, 69 In
this work, Lee and Messersmith demonstrated that PDA could
be formed by the self-polymerization of dopamine in rather mild conditions. 68 More importantly, the PDA could provide a
useful platform for the secondary reactions and thus
introducing a various functional components on almost any materials. 70, 71 On the other hand, PDA can also be utilized for
preparation of functional polymeric nanostructures and N
doped carbon nanomaterials. To date, a variety of surface
modification strategies have been developed and different
PDA based nanomaterials have been fabricated over the last decade. 72-80 Mussel inspired chemistry and PDA based
materials have been extensively explored for different
applications ranged from bioadhensives, enzyme
immobilization, fluorescent imaging and sensors, cancer
treatment, anti-bacterial to environment remediation and energy storage and conversion. 81-95 For example, Lu et al. have
recently synthesized the colloidal nanospheres based on
dopamine-melanin through self-polymerization of dopamine in
water/ethanol mixture. The size of these PDA nanospheres can
be well controlled through adjusting the experimental conditions. 96 Moreover, the PDA nanospheres showed high
biodegradability, biocompatibility and excellent photothermal
conversion efficiency (40 %) (Fig. 7). The biological results
indicated that PDA nanospheres can be used as novel and

sections.heading: 3. Imaging-guided PTT
sections.text:
Nanotheranostics that combined the imaging signals with
therapeutic agents together has attracted much more research attention recently. 99, 100 Various medical imaging models such
as fluorescence imaging, positron emission tomography,
single-photon emission computed tomography, magnetic
resonance imaging, sonography and photoacoustic imaging,
Raman spectral mapping etc have been utilized to combine
with different therapeutic components to form multifunctional theranostic systems. 101-111 Among them, the integration of one
or more imaging signals with photothermal agents can be
applied for fabrication of imaging-guided PTT systems, which
are often obtained by incorporating inorganic nanoparticles
such as Fe3O4, indium tin oxide into polymers with photothermal conversion capability. 63, 112-114 However, the
polymeric imaging-guided PTT systems have received only
relative little interest. In the following section, some excellent
examples of imaging-guided PTT systems based on pure
polymers were summarized.
Fluorescent imaging is a very useful and commonly adopted
imaging technique. The fabrication of fluorescent imaging-
guided PTT using polymeric nanostructures has been extensively developed over the past decades. 115 Indocyanine
green (ICG) is a cyanine dye, which has been granted by FDA
approval in 1959. The ICG is a NIR fluorescent dye and could
also adsorb the laser at about 790 nm, which could be applied
for enhancing the laser uptake by targeted tissue and therefore for laser welding. 116, 117 It is therefore, ICG is suitable
for fluorescent imaging of living organisms and potentially
used for PTT applications. In other word, the ICG can be used
for fluorescent imaging and PTT simultaneously. Over the past
several decades, a number of studies have investigated the
imaging-guided PTT applications based on ICG. For example,
Chen et al have previously investigated the laser-
photosensitizer assisted immunotherapy applications using ICG and immunoadjuvant agents in detailed. 118-121 More
recently, the incorporation of ICG into synthetic polymers (PL-
PEG) to overcome the disadvantages of ICG was also demonstrated by Xing et al. 122 In this work, ICG was
encapsulated by amphiphilic PL-PEG through the hydrophobic
interactions. Then the two targeting agents, folic acid (FA) and
integrin αvβ3 monoclonal antibody were conjugated with PL-
PEG. In vitro experimental results demonstrated that these ICG
containing polymeric nanostructures can be selectively
internalized by cells through ligand−receptor mediated
endocytosis pathway. The fluorescent imaging and
photothermal effects made ICG containing polymeric
nanostructures promising for fabricating multifunctional
probes for imaging-guided PTT applications. In a more recent
study, Cai et al reported the chemo-photothermal combination
therapy through loading of anticancer agent (DOX) and ICG
into poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA)–lecithin–polyethylene
glycol (PEG) simultaneously. The results suggested that the
chemo-PTT polymeric nanoparticles showed synergistical effects to suppress tumor growth. 123 Furthermore, Cai et al
have developed another multi-modal imaging-guided cancer PTT platform through the simple adsorption of ICG and Fe 3+ on PDA nanospheres. 102 Results demonstrated that the
adsorption of ICG on PDA nanospheres could obviously
enhance the optical adsorption of PDA nanospheres in NIR
region (Fig. 8). The above property could be utilized for the
photoacoustic imaging. On the other hand, the adsorption of Fe 3+ on PDA nanospheres endowed their capability for
magnetic resonance imaging applications. Therefore, PDA– Fe 3+ –ICG NPs showed excellent PTT effects at low laser density.
This work provided a facile and versatile method for
fabricating multi-modal imaging-guided PTT platform.

Fig. 8 The synthesis and characterization of the PDA–Fe 3+ –ICG NPs. (a) A schematic illustration of the preparation process of PDA–Fe 3+ –ICG NPs. (b) A SEM image of the PDA–Fe 3+ –ICG NPs. (c) Hydrodynamic diameters of the PDA NPs and PDA–Fe 3+ –ICG NPs measured using DLS. (d) UV-Vis absorption spectra of the PDA NPs, PDA–Fe 3+ NPs and PDA–Fe 3+ –ICG NPs. (e) Fluorescence emission spectra of equal free ICG and PDA–Fe 3+ – ICG NPs. (Reproduced from Ref. 102 with permission).
Aggregation-induced emission (AIE) is a unique fluorescence
phenomenon and has been extensively adopted for fabricating of functional materials for different applications. 124 The
fabrication of AIE-active fluorescent polymeric nanoprobes for
biological imaging has become one of the most important research topics in the AIE related fields. 125-137 The
incorporation of AIE-active dyes into water soluble and
biocompatible polymers could elegantly overcome the
aggregation caused quenching (ACQ) effect of conventional
organic dyes and their poor water dispersibility. Over the past
few years, a large number of AIE-active polymeric nanoprobes
have been prepared through different strategies such as non-
covalent encapsulation, covalent conjugation, living radical
polymerization, ring-opening reaction, formation of dynamic bonds and host-guest interactions. 105, 106, 108-111, 138-142 The
fabrication of fluorescent imaging-guided phototherapy
applications have also demonstrated by some groups. In
particular, we have recently reported the first AIE-active dye
based targeted nanotheranostics through the encapsulation of
AIE-active dye (PhENH2), anticancer drug (paclitaxel) and PPy into human serum albumin (HSA). 143 Then cyclic arginine–
glycine–aspartic acid (cRGD) as the targeting moiety was self-
assembled with the above described agents to enhance their
targeting capability (Fig. 9). The fluorescent characterization
confirmed that the final product emitted strong luminescence
after self-assembly with PPy. Biological results indicated that
human serum albumin-PhENH2-PPy-PTX-cRGD showed strong
fluorescence after 48 h intravenous injection and effective
tumor eradicated performance. Therefore, the AIE-active
imaging-guided multifunctional system should be a novel and
effective platform for different biomedical applications due to
their unique AIE fluorescent property and high tumor PTT
performance.
Fig. 9 Schematic illustration of the synthesis and application of AIE fluorogen based targeted nanotheranostics. (a) In vivo fluorescence images of U87MG tumor-bearing nude mice taken at different time points post iv injection of HSA-PhENH2-PPy-PTX and HSA-PhENH2-PPy-PTX-cRGD (doses: PhENH2 1.5 mg kg–1, PPy 6.7 mg kg–1). (b) Ex vivo fluorescence images of major organs (liver, heart, spleen, kidney, lung) and tumor dissected from mice injected with HSA-PhENH2-PPy-PTX and HSA-PhENH2-PPy-PTXcRGD (48 h post iv injection). (c) Semiquantitative biodistribution of HSA-PhENH2-PPyPTX and HSA-PhENH2-PPy-PTX-cRGD in various organs as determined by the fluorescence intensities measured in (B). The data are shown as mean ± SD (n = 3). (Reproduced from Ref. 143 with permission).
Inspired by the binding capability of PDA with iron ion, Lu et
al developed a novel multifunctional theranostic system. As
shown in Fig. 10, PDAs@CP3 core-shell nanostructure was prepared via layer by layer self-assembly procedure in the
present of iron ion. The porous and biodegradable PDAs@CP3 can be utilized for loading anticancer agent (DOX) with high
efficiency. In vitro results demonstrated that PDAs@CP3 exhibited good biocompatibility and can be used for loading
DOX for cancer therapy applications. However, as compared
with the samples without irradiation with laser, the samples
irradiation with laser could significantly improve their
therapeutic efficiency (Fig. 10a). In vivo evaluation results
confirmed that the PDAs@CP3 displayed excellent photothermal conversion efficiency and could great improve

Tumor growth curves of mice after various treatments (*p < 0.05, by ANOVA with Tukey's post-test) (e). (reprinted with permission from Ref. 101 .)
Liu et al. also developed image-guided PTAs, CP
microparticles (CP MPs), based on PFTTQ poly(9,9-
dihexylfluorene-alt-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole) (PFBT) by physical blend (Fig. 11). 44 The CP MPs, a diameter around 3 μm, can
select image to MCF-7 cells, U87MG brain cancer cells and C6
glioma cells. Meanwhile, the CP MPs has excellent
photostability as the fluorescence loss was less than 8% after
10 min laser scanning continuously. In standard
methylthiazolyldiphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assays, the
viability of MCF-7 cancer cells was less than 20% after incubation in CP MPs and laser treatment of 808 nm (1 W cm -2 ,
10 min).
Fig. 11 (a) Chemical structures of PFBT and PFTTQ (b) Schematic illustration of CP MPs formation. (Reproduced from Ref. 44 with permission.)

sections.heading: 4. Photothermal combination therapy
sections.text:
The combination of other therapy such as chemotherapy,
photodynamic therapy, gene therapy and radiotherapy models
with PTT might provide better therapeutic performance as
compared with the PTT alone. Some examples about these
multifunctional PTAs based combination therapy strategies have recently attracted increasing research interest. 144-147 For
example, Liu et al have demonstrated that graphene oxide can
be covalently functionalized with PEG and polyethylenimine (PEI) at the same time. 144 The final NGO-PEG-PEI
nanocompsites showed high stability under physiological
solution and can be loaded with functional DNA. The results
suggested that the plasmid DNA transfection efficiency could
be largely enhanced under NIR laser irradiation, resulting in
significant down-regulation of targeting gene. On the other
hand, the energy of NIR laser could also be absorbed by NGO
and converted into heat, which can be used for PTT purpose. More recently, the radioactive 64 Cu containing CuS NPs were
used for the combination of photothermal and radiotherapy applications by Li et al. 146 The therapeutic system is mainly
relied on the plasmonic properties of Cu NPs and the radiptherapeutic property of 64 Cu. These radioactive Cu NPs
were facilely fabricated through a one-pot route using PEG-SH
as the polymer coating. Results showed that the final PEG[ 64 Cu]CuS NPs micro-PET/CT imaging and combination of PTT
and radiotherapy. Furthermore, the multimodel imaging
combination of photothermal/radiotherapy synergistic therapy has also recently reported by Zhao et al. 147 The combination
other therapeutic models with PTT should be of great research
interest in improving the therapeutic efficiency. However, the
photothermal combination therapy systems based on the
polymeric PTAs have received only very limited attention.
Some examples about these combination therapeutic models
such as chemotherapy-combined PTT and photodynamic-
combined PTT were listed below.

sections.heading: 4.1 Chemotherapy –combined PTT
sections.text:
Liu et al. integrated PFTTQ with DOX and cyclic arginine-
glycine-aspartic acid (cRGD) tripeptide, and fabricated NPs for
the synchronous chemo- and photothermal therapy (Fig. 12). 148 Poly-L-lysine-g-PEG bearing some 2-diazo-1,2-
naphthoquinones (DNQ) moieties as the encapsulation matrix

can transform from hydrophobic to hydrophilic under NIR two-
photo laser irradiation, which would control the release of
DOX. Thus, the PTT of PFTTQ and chemotherapy of DOX can be
simultaneously triggered by two-photo laser irradiation.
Moreover, the cRGD tripeptide on the surface emphasized the
target of the NPs to cancer cells. In MTT assay, the half-
maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) of the NPs to MDA-MB231 cells for combination therapy is 13.7 µg mL -1 compared to the 147.8 µg mL -1 of solely chemotherapy and 36.2 µg mL -1 of
PTT. Obviously, the synergistic cell inhibition of the NPs was of
considerable advantage.
Fig. 12 Schematic illustration of PLL-g-PEG/DNQ (PFTTQ/DOX NPs) formation and the combination photothermal and chemotherapy regulated by two-photon laser (Reproduced from Ref. 148 with permission.)
Based on the study of dopamine as PTA, the combination of
chemotherapy and PTT was further developed. Wu et al.
synthesized a smart core–shell Dox-M@PDA–Btz nanoparticles
applying doxorubicin and dopamine as chemotherapy agents and PTA, respectively (Fig. 13a). 149 The shell of dopamine was
modified by Btz and formed pH-sensitive boronic acid which
can be dissociated and release Btz in a low pH environment
(Fig. 13b). Notly, the release of Btz and DOX can be strongly
enhanced by NIR irradiation as the heat stimulates the
dissociation of interaction between DOX and micelle. Besides,
the PTT of the NPs was still kept as the temperature of NPs
increased under NIR irradiation. The antitumor activity of the
NPs in vivo was quite outstanding, and showed complete
inhabitation without recurrence. Meanwhile, the organ
function of mice treatmented was close to normal lever.
Similarly, a sweet DOX-loaded nanoparticles PLDA-DA was synthesized by Dong’s group 150 . The NPs consisted by
lactosylated dopamine and DOX exhibited the capability of
target to HepG2 cells, PTT and chemotherapy (Fig. 13c).
Moreover, the synergistic curative effect was better than
single of chemotherapy or PTT. A kind of core-shell polymer
nanoparticles were also designed for chemo-photothermal
employing micelle encapsulating doxorubicin and PDA as core and shell, respectively. 151 In addition, PEGylated polydopamine
loaded doxorubicin and 7-ethyl-10-hydroxycamptothecin have been reported for multifunctional nanotheranostic systems. 152, 153
Fig. 13 (a) Schematic illustration of core – shell Dox-M@PDA – Btz nanoparticles formation (b) drug delivery and photothermal therapy of core – shell Dox-M@PDA – Btz nanoparticles (c) Illustration of one-pot preparation of the sweet DOX-loaded nanoparticles PLDA-DA. (Reproduced from Ref. 149, 150 with permission.)

sections.heading: 4.2 Photodynamic–combined PTT
sections.text:
Photodynamic therapy (PDT), applied the reactive oxide
species (ROS) produced by photosensitizer under laser
irradiation to induce the apoptosis of cancer cells, has
attracted more attention as the increasing of the cancer
morbidity. Some work about synergistic of PDT and PTT has
been done. For example, Liu et al. produced lipid-Gd-
gadolinium-1,4,7,10-tetraacetic acid micelles packaged with
semiconducting polymer dots and chlorin e6 for
MRI/photoacoustic imaging and PDT/PTT (Pdots/Ce6@lipid– Gd–DOTA micelles). 154 Semiconducting π-conjunction polymer,
poly[2,6-(4,4-bis-(2-ethylhexyl)-4H-cyclopenta[2,1-b;3,4-b`]-
dithiophene)-alt-4,7-(2,1,3-benzo-thiadiazole)] (PCPDTBT), was
introduced as PTA (Fig. 14a). In the system, the ROS
generation of Ce6 and the photothermal conversion of
PCPDTBT were not decreased. In vivo, the temperature of
tumor sites increased more than 20 °C under NIR laser
irradiation (670 nm, 2 min) after injecting Pdots/Ce6@lipid–
Gd–DOTA micelles (Fig. 14b). The tumor inhibition
experiments revealed the tumor growth was restained more
than 19 days by Pdots/Ce6@lipid–Gd–DOTA micelles, while
the body weight of mice treated by Pdots/Ce6@lipid–Gd–
DOTA micelles had no obvious loss (Fig. 14c). Liu et al. applied
PPy, Ce6 and bovine serum albumin (BSA) as PTA, PDA and
stabilizing agent to fabricate PPy@BSA-Ce6, and the results in
vivo confirmed an improved synergistic therapeutic effect was achieved by PPy@BSA-Ce6. 155 In addition, Ma et al. developed
dual-modal PDT/PTT based on indocyanine green (ICG) and PEDOT. 156

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In recent years, the functional polymers have been
extensively explored in biomedical fields for diagnosis,
treatment, organ repair and regeneration because of its well
designability, biodegradability and biocompatibility.
Developing polymeric molecules as PTAs also investigated for
years. In this review, the conjugated polymers (e.g. polyaniline,
PPy), melanin-like polymers, imaging-guided polymeric PTT
and photothermal combination therapy were introduced.
Because of the advantages in dispersibility and
biocompatibility, some of these polymeric PTAs (e.g. melanin-
like polymers) have been regarded as the promising candidates
for PTT applications. Despite great advances including the
introduction of more types polymeric PTAs and the
combination with other treatments have recently been
achieved in the development of polymeric PTAs, there still
have many challenges should be encountered. First, there is
still much work need to be done for controlling their
physicochemical properties (e.g. size, morphology and
biodegradability), maximize their therapeutic effect while
minimize toxicity. On the other hand, although many
polymeric PTAs have shown great potential for cancer
treatment, the detailed information about their long-term
distribution behavior, degradation and toxicity is still lack.
More data about their pharmacokinetics, long-term toxicity
and degradation properties should be obtained before their
potential clinical applications. Another big challenge for the
cilinical applications of PTT is for the tumors in deep tissues
and metastatic cancer. Therefore, the integration of
collaborative treatment and systematic treatment models is
advocated to be developed. Based on these above listed issues,
the future direction should be focused on the following
aspects. 1) Searching novel biodegradable and biocompatible
PTAs with high photothermal conversion efficiency from small
organic molecules, 2) developing organic and inorganic hybrid
composites (e.g. metal organic framework, metal ions (e.g. Fe 3+ , Zn 2+ ) enhanced polymeric PTAs), 3) preparation of novel
degradable and biocompatible PTAs through conjugation
oligomers of CPs through dynamic bonds.
